subject: Cage Matches
event:
The Suvudu cage match is going down to the wire.  More than 26,000 votes cast, I am astonished to see.  Last time I looked Jaime was down about 130 votes.  If you'd like to cast a vote or make a comment on the match, go to

http://www.suvudu.com/2010/04/cage-match-2010-championship-5-rand-althor-versus-15-jaime-lannister.html#more

But do it soon.  Voting closes at 8pm Eastern.

All this interest in imaginary people fighting other imaginary people while their respective fans pontificate about who would win and why has already prompted one well regarded book blog to denounce the whole thing as nerdism.  Well, hell.  Maybe so.  

(But then again, nerds now rule the world.  Or is that geeks?  I always get the two confused.  Geeks are the ones who bite the heads off chickens, I recall, but... ) 

It is true that only fantasy fans seem to go in for this sort of thing.  Though perhaps Suvudu should follow this tournament with another one for SF characters.  The Shrike could have another chance (he didn't really belong in the fantasy tournament), and so could Arthur Dent (ditto).  But think of all the other great characters they could bring in.  Michael Valentine Smith.  The Grey Lensman.  The Ship Who Sang.  Paul Atreides.  Hari Seldon.  The Stainless Steel Rat.  Honor Harrington.  Miles Vorkosigan.  Captain Future.  R. Daneel Olivaw.  Sam.  Blackie Duquesne.  Nicholas van Rijn.  Kirth Gerson.  Bill, the Galactic Hero.  Jonathan Hoag.  Odd John.  C'mell.  Golden Boy, Jack Braun.  Retief.  One of Fred Saberhagen's berserkers.  But no, NOT Han Solo or Captain Kirk, please, leave the TV and film characters out of it, or they'd dominate.  (Well, except for Pinto Vortando.  You can include Pinto Vortando.  His fandom is very small).  

Even better, why not a MAINSTREAM cage match?  Just think of the matches!  The Great Gatsby v. Ebeneezer Scrooge.  Madame Bovary v. Tom Jones.  Huck Finn v. Lord Jim.  Wilfrid of Ivanhoe v. Rabbit Angstrom.  Jane Eyre v. Portnoy.  Scarlett O'Hara v. Sammy Glick.  Oliver Twist v. Captain Ahab.  Lenny and George (got to keep them as a team) v. Silas Marner.

snorf

comments.article:
I always get the two confused.


Nerds are smart, if dorky at times. Geeks . . . not so much.

That doesn't agree with the common usage of the terms today. This venn diagram sums it up pretty well:

http://www.slashfilm.com/2010/03/26/venn-diagram-the-difference-between-geek-nerd-dork-and-dweeb/
Reading that SF list, I can't help but just automatically assume Miles Vorkosigan would win. :)
Yeah, Miles might even be a match for Tyrion. :)

I'm completely caught up in the Thunderdome of this final match. All the write ups were so fun to read. I have my passionate favorite, and the drama of watching the numbers - within one hundred - is thrilling. It reminds me of why I like sports drama.

The thing that is least surprising and most disheartening are the vitriolic responses, the venom and the fury that comes with one side debating over another. It stops becoming fun, and starts becoming... well... life. It's no longer fantasy, a new world to dream and explore, new characters and families to love, hate, weep with... it becomes Capitol Hill, the world at large with its real wars. It is, I suppose, human nature, which can still make me sad.

BUT NOT SAD ENOUGH TO NOT VOTE FOR JAIME! (Just sad enough to keep me from reading comments.)
comments.subject: Strangely amused

comments.article: Let's not forget the ladies.   Pyanfar from the Chanur tales would have a pretty good chance.
He's getting there, only 68 behind now :o)

"... has already prompted one well regarded book blog to denounce the whole thing as nerdism."

Some people like hearing themselves pontificate. ;)

I admit amazement at there being over 1,000 comments in that thread, though. Wow. I'm urging people on to see if we can get it to over 30,000 votes. It's fun to make the Rand supporters sweat. ;)

As to whether it's more a fantasy thing or not ... Huh. I guess so. I think maybe SF fans would quickly run into problems trying to look at it empirically than fantasy fans. Although I think one might find that SF fans would more readily discuss "Which science fiction weapon/spaceship is best?" than actual characters.

In any case, everyone knows that the Offensive Unit All Through With This Niceness And Negotiation Stuff would win an SF cagematch. Or maybe Gravitas... Gravitas... No, Don't Help Me, I'll Get It In A Moment...
Hello Dolly vs the Merry Widow

There's been some cross-over one on ones in detective fiction over the years - in particular Sherlock Holmes has been paired up against Fu Manchu on more than one occasion (and against Dracula, for that matter. And, in one comic, against Batman). And of course it's a regular occurence in comics - although I guess they come under the fantasy banner.

Mind you, imagine some of the characters from fiction turning up in Westeros - Tyrion can outhink most people - how would he fair against Iago?

comments.upictitle: Thoughts of a nerdy feminist: pic#124268277
comments.article:
I already posted a link to it on my journal here and in my facebook, telling people to vote for Jaime. At one point, I saw Rand ahead by one vote. This is really close.

Personally, I'd like to see Lestat versus Edward Cullen.
I would be entirely shocked if a slashfic doesn't already exist, on this.

if I could be allowed to add a name to the list for the sci-fi fights I'd have to add Heinlein's Johnie Rico, what's not to love about a man who essentialy walks around as a tank while considering deep philosphycal issues like rights and the death penalty.
Agreeing with a previous comment - where are the women?  For every Miles Vorkosigan, there's definitely a Cordelia to kick ass and take names right alongside!

It's not in the least bit limited to fantasy. Google "Enterprise Versus Star Destroyer" sometime.

Heck, pro sports and American Idol are pretty much the same thing. Of course, watching ESPN or reality TV can't possibly be nerdy because... uh... more people do it. (Not knocking them, by the way, just pointing out that anyone who watches Idol but sneers at Suvudu's Cage Match is being more than a little hypocritical.)
After voting just now I see it's even closer than you said...Jaime is ahead by a margin of only SEVENTEEN VOTES! (13,629 to 13,612)

I like the idea of the generalized literary cage matches. I will note that there's a game called "Who Would Win?", where you choose two names from a stack of cards, and one contest, and then the two players (or more, I suppose), try and make the most convincing arguement as to why that person would win that contest. It's very silly.

(And I note that you fixed my favorite typo from yesterday's story, when you left the final letter of the phrase "warriors without peer".)

As of 1236 hours PST, Jaime is currently ahead.

...By 20 votes.

This is gonna be a nail-biter.
Right now Jaime's winning by 19 votes. 19, people!!!! Come on, everybody cast a vote! This is a tough one!
I mean, not that I don't like Rand or anything... I've voted for him on other matches, but between the two of them, and especially between WoT and ASoIaF, I'm going for Jaime and ASoIaF. Go Jaime!

comments.upictitle: Random Writings: Enter At Own Risk
comments.article: I've been obsessively checking the voting all day. As I wrote this, Jaime held a TWO VOTE lead over Rand. Out of over 27,000 votes cast. How crazy cool is that? :-)
The vote difference is something like 10-20 votes now - just voted for Jaime!
Right now Jaime has 11 votes more than Rand. It seems we're gonna have an interesting fight.
I'd go for an all-out battle between the Morlocks and the Liliputians! Btw George,Warriors without pee?!? That was one of the more comical typos I've run across in a while! Great story though!

I admit to my nerddom, and I'm proud of it. :)

I'm all for more cage matches. We could do some historical characters as well. Would Napoleon have succeeded where Vercingetorix failed against Caesar, or would Caesar have won against Kutusov? Could Wallenstein have stopped Alexander the Great, or Arminuis taken up Attila? Though we probably should allow them an army; it just dawned to me that most successful historical leaders have won because of their skills as generals, not because they personally kicked ass (though some, like Arminius and Attila were no mean fighters themselves).

comments.upictitle: Stop drooling at my pic!!!!: Author pose
comments.article:
I would define Nerd as someone who studies all the time.
Dork is someone that is socially awkward
And Geek is someone who is very enthusiastic about a subject.
Sometimes the three are intertwined.

In an all-street-rat edition I wouldn't have minded seeing Arya vs. the Artful Dodger (hey, it's not as easy as you think, don't sell Jack short).

Good luck to Jaime in these final hours. I've garnered at least thirty votes from my pool of geek (because most of us really ain't all THAT smart) friends, so hopefully that's enough.

Of course what we're REALLY waiting for are the next wave of George's infamous casting clues. (The fact that someone actually got Isaac Hempstead-Wright correct is still mind-boggling to me. Welcome to the Google age, I guess...)

Fun times. Twenty years from now George look back at this odd cat-and-mouse casting game he played and have himself a grin, methinks. He confounded us, at times, and we have surprised him too.

And we only get as many of these little tidbits as we have core ASoIaF characters. Littlefinger, Varys, Tywin, Hodor ... I'm not sure Old Nan counts as a core charatcer, but hey, I'd want that clue too.
comments.subject: Down to the wire...

comments.article:
all three speak for an oddness of character, with nerds it tends to be related to schoolwork, to be a geek speaks for obsession, there is something that they know an absurd amount about getting to know every facet of that thing, as someone who plays strategy games this is the category i run into the most, there are so many types of geeks after all. I think I myself would fall into dork which more along the lines quirky, strange and random with no particular area of oddness just overall.

that's my interpretation of the whole thing.
comments.subject: geeks,nerds and dorks
